PAGEINFO.PageTitle: Sort Pictures: Solar Min vs Solar Max
PAGEINFO.instructions_body:
Sort pictures of the Sun!

Drag the small pictures of the Sun on the left to the Solar Maximum or Solar Minimum areas on the right.

The small images to your left are all pictures of the Sun. Some show the Sun at times called Solar Max, when there are lots of sunspots. Others show the Sun near Solar Min, when there are few or no sunspots.

Drag each picture into the correct group on the right - Solar Max or Solar Min.

The pictures were taken with different wavelengths of light, such as X-rays or ultraviolet light.

The first two - in the upper left, Visible 2006 and Visible 2001 - are easy. The others are a bit trickier!

Once you master this level, try the Sort Features by Temperature level of the Sun Sorting Game.

PAGEINFO.choose_level_body: <form action="#"><fieldset><label for="level">Select a level</label><select name="level" id="level"><option>Level 1</option><option>Level 2</option></select></fieldset></form>

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Visible 2006
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This photo shows the Sun in visible light. You cannot look directly at the Sun without harming your eyes! If you could, this is about what you might see. The number of sunspots increases and then decreases in a repeating cycle that lasts about 11 years. This photo shows the Sun at the "solar min" phase of the sunspot cycle, when there are very few sunspots.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This photo shows the Sun in visible light. You cannot look directly at the Sun without harming your eyes! If you could, this is about what you might see. The number of sunspots increases and then decreases in a repeating cycle that lasts about 11 years. This photo shows the Sun at the "solar min" phase of the sunspot cycle, when there are very few sunspots.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Visible 2001
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This photo shows the Sun in visible light. You cannot look directly at the Sun without harming your eyes! If you could, this is about what you might see. The number of sunspots increases and then decreases in a repeating cycle that lasts about 11 years. This photo shows the Sun at the "solar max" phase of the Sunspot Cycle, when there are lots of sunspots.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This photo shows the Sun in visible light. You cannot look directly at the Sun without harming your eyes! If you could, this is about what you might see. The number of sunspots increases and then decreases in a repeating cycle that lasts about 11 years. This photo shows the Sun at the "solar max" phase of the Sunspot Cycle, when there are lots of sunspots.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: UV 2009
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This picture shows the Sun in ultraviolet (UV) "light". Powerful magnetic fields around sunspots produce disturbances in the Sun's atmosphere. These disturbances give off high-energy radiation in the form of UV light and X-rays. During solar min, when there are few sunspots, UV pictures of the Sun look mostly plain and feature-less.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This picture shows the Sun in ultraviolet (UV) "light". Powerful magnetic fields around sunspots produce disturbances in the Sun's atmosphere. These disturbances give off high-energy radiation in the form of UV light and X-rays. During solar min, when there are few sunspots, UV pictures of the Sun look mostly plain and feature-less.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: X-ray 2001
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This picture shows how the Sun would look if you had X-ray vision! Powerful magnetic fields around sunspots produce disturbances in the Sun's atmosphere. These disturbances give off high-energy radiation in the form of X-rays and ultraviolet "light". Around solar max, when there are lots of sunspots, X-ray pictures of the Sun show many bright areas. The bright regions appear in the Sun's atmosphere above sunspots.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This picture shows how the Sun would look if you had X-ray vision! Powerful magnetic fields around sunspots produce disturbances in the Sun's atmosphere. These disturbances give off high-energy radiation in the form of X-rays and ultraviolet "light". Around solar max, when there are lots of sunspots, X-ray pictures of the Sun show many bright areas. The bright regions appear in the Sun's atmosphere above sunspots.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: X-ray 1996
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This picture shows how the Sun would look if you had X-ray vision! Powerful magnetic fields around sunspots produce disturbances in the Sun's atmosphere. These disturbances give off high-energy radiation in the form of X-rays and ultraviolet "light". During solar min, when there are few sunspots, X-ray pictures of the Sun look relatively plain. They show just a scattering of small, bright dots where X-rays are being emitted.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This picture shows how the Sun would look if you had X-ray vision! Powerful magnetic fields around sunspots produce disturbances in the Sun's atmosphere. These disturbances give off high-energy radiation in the form of X-rays and ultraviolet "light". During solar min, when there are few sunspots, X-ray pictures of the Sun look relatively plain. They show just a scattering of small, bright dots where X-rays are being emitted.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: UV 2002
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This picture shows the Sun in ultraviolet (UV) "light". Powerful magnetic fields around sunspots produce disturbances in the Sun's atmosphere. These disturbances give off high-energy radiation in the form of UV light and X-rays. During solar max, when there are lots of sunspots, UV pictures of the Sun show many bright areas. The bright regions appear in the Sun's atmosphere above sunspots.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This picture shows the Sun in ultraviolet (UV) "light". Powerful magnetic fields around sunspots produce disturbances in the Sun's atmosphere. These disturbances give off high-energy radiation in the form of UV light and X-rays. During solar max, when there are lots of sunspots, UV pictures of the Sun show many bright areas. The bright regions appear in the Sun's atmosphere above sunspots.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Corona 1994
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This photo shows the corona, the outer, uppermost part of the Sun's atmosphere. The picture was taken during a solar eclipse, when the Moon blocks out the Sun. At solar min, when there are few sunspots, the corona is brightest around the Sun's equator. Around solar min, the corona looks like a pair of wings on either side of the Sun.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This photo shows the corona, the outer, uppermost part of the Sun's atmosphere. The picture was taken during a solar eclipse, when the Moon blocks out the Sun. At solar min, when there are few sunspots, the corona is brightest around the Sun's equator. Around solar min, the corona looks like a pair of wings on either side of the Sun.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Corona 1980
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This photo shows the corona, the outer, uppermost part of the Sun's atmosphere. The picture was taken during a solar eclipse, when the Moon blocks out the Sun. At solar max, when there are lots of sunspots, the corona streams outward from the Sun in all directions.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This photo shows the corona, the outer, uppermost part of the Sun's atmosphere. The picture was taken during a solar eclipse, when the Moon blocks out the Sun. At solar max, when there are lots of sunspots, the corona streams outward from the Sun in all directions.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Magnet 2002
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This a special type of picture of the Sun called a "magnetogram". It is a map of magnetic fields on the Sun. Black and white areas on a magnetogram show areas of different "polarity" of magnetic fields - like the North and South poles of a bar magnet. Sunspots have very, very strong magnetic fields. When there are lots of sunspots at solar max, a magnetogram has alternating patches of black and white - showing us the strong magnetic fields around sunspots.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This a special type of picture of the Sun called a "magnetogram". It is a map of magnetic fields on the Sun. Black and white areas on a magnetogram show areas of different "polarity" of magnetic fields - like the North and South poles of a bar magnet. Sunspots have very, very strong magnetic fields. When there are lots of sunspots at solar max, a magnetogram has alternating patches of black and white - showing us the strong magnetic fields around sunspots.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: H-alpha 2009
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This picture shows the Sun as viewed in a specific wavelength of red light given off by hydrogen atoms. Scientists call this a Hydrogen-alpha (or H-alpha) image. It shows the lower part of the Sun's atmosphere, called the chromosphere. During solar min, when there are few sunspots, H-alpha pictures of the Sun look mostly plain and feature-less.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This picture shows the Sun as viewed in a specific wavelength of red light given off by hydrogen atoms. Scientists call this a Hydrogen-alpha (or H-alpha) image. It shows the lower part of the Sun's atmosphere, called the chromosphere. During solar min, when there are few sunspots, H-alpha pictures of the Sun look mostly plain and feature-less.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: H-alpha 2000
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This picture shows the Sun as viewed in a specific wavelength of red light given off by hydrogen atoms. Scientists call this a Hydrogen-alpha (or H-alpha) image. It shows the lower part of the Sun's atmosphere, called the chromosphere. During solar max, when there are lots of sunspots, powerful magnetic fields around sunspots "stir up" the solar atmosphere above sunspots. Around solar max, H-alpha pictures have a mixture of brighter and dimmer regions. They also show squiggly lines called "filaments".
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This picture shows the Sun as viewed in a specific wavelength of red light given off by hydrogen atoms. Scientists call this a Hydrogen-alpha (or H-alpha) image. It shows the lower part of the Sun's atmosphere, called the chromosphere. During solar max, when there are lots of sunspots, powerful magnetic fields around sunspots "stir up" the solar atmosphere above sunspots. Around solar max, H-alpha pictures have a mixture of brighter and dimmer regions. They also show squiggly lines called "filaments".

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Magnet 2006
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: This a special type of picture of the Sun called a "magnetogram". It is a map of magnetic fields on the Sun. Black and white areas on a magnetogram show areas of different "polarity" of magnetic fields - like the North and South poles of a bar magnet. Sunspots have very, very strong magnetic fields. When there are few sunspots at solar min, a magnetogram is pretty plain and boring. The Sun looks like a uniformly gray ball because its magnetic field is pretty much the same across its surface.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: This a special type of picture of the Sun called a "magnetogram". It is a map of magnetic fields on the Sun. Black and white areas on a magnetogram show areas of different "polarity" of magnetic fields - like the North and South poles of a bar magnet. Sunspots have very, very strong magnetic fields. When there are few sunspots at solar min, a magnetogram is pretty plain and boring. The Sun looks like a uniformly gray ball because its magnetic field is pretty much the same across its surface.
